reference.shortdesc: A long quotation is a quotation that contains one or more paragraphs. Authors can specify the title and source of the document that is being quoted.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: Authors can use the href and keyref attributes to specify the source of the quotation. Use the quote element q for short quotations that are intended to be rendered inline.The longquoteref element is available for more complex references to the source of a quotation.

section.title: Formatting expectations
section.p: Although rendering is left up to implementations, processors generally render lq as an indented block.

section.title: Attributes
section.p: The following attributes are available on this element: , (with a narrowed definition for type, given below), and keyref, and the attributes defined below.

dlentry.dd: The title of the document or topic being quoted.
Indicates the location of the source of the quote. See for detailed information on the usual supported values and processing implications.

example.title: Example
example.p: The following code example contains a quotation. The reftitle attribute specifies the title of the document that is quoted, and the href attribute indicates a Web site where the full text of the address can be accessed.
example.codeblock:
This is the first line of the address that Abraham Lincoln delivered on November 19, 1863 for the dedication of the cemetery at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.

Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.
example.p: When processed, the output might look like the following:
This is the first line of the address that Abraham Lincoln delivered on November 19, 1863 for the dedication of the cemetery at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.
example.lq: Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.
